meta.title: MentalBench: A Benchmark for Evaluating Psychiatric Diagnostic Capability of Large Language Models
meta.summary: We introduce MentalBench, a benchmark for evaluating psychiatric diagnostic decision-making in large language models (LLMs). Existing mental health benchmarks largely rely on social media data, limiting their ability to assess DSM-grounded diagnostic judgments. At the core of MentalBench is MentalKG, a psychiatrist-built and validated knowledge graph encoding DSM-5 diagnostic criteria and differential diagnostic rules for 23 psychiatric disorders. Using MentalKG as a golden-standard logical backbone, we generate 24,750 synthetic clinical cases that systematically vary in information completeness and diagnostic complexity, enabling low-noise and interpretable evaluation. Our experiments show that while state-of-the-art LLMs perform well on structured queries probing DSM-5 knowledge, they struggle to calibrate confidence in diagnostic decision-making when distinguishing between clinically overlapping disorders. These findings reveal evaluation gaps not captured by existing benchmarks.
meta.query: (cat:cs.CL OR cat:cs.LG) AND (all:"large language model" OR all:LLM) AND (all:medical OR all:clinical OR all:healthcare)

pages.text:
MENTALBENCH: A Benchmark for Evaluating Psychiatric Diagnostic
Capability of Large Language Models
Hoyun Song1*
Migyeong Kang2*
Jisu Shin1
Jihyun Kim2
Chanbi Park3
Hangyeol Yoo4
Jihyun An5
Alice Oh1
Jinyoung Han2†
KyungTae Lim1†
1Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
2Sungkyunkwan University
3Dongguk University Medical Center
4Seoul National University of Science and Technology (Seoultech)
5Samsung Medical Center
{hysong, ktlim}@kaist.ac.kr
gy77@g.skku.edu
jinyounghan@skku.edu
Abstract
We introduce MENTALBENCH, a benchmark
for evaluating psychiatric diagnostic decision-
making in large language models (LLMs). Ex-
isting mental health benchmarks largely rely on
social media data, limiting their ability to as-
sess DSM-grounded diagnostic judgments. At
the core of MENTALBENCH is MENTALKG,
a psychiatrist-built and validated knowledge
graph encoding DSM-5 diagnostic criteria
and differential diagnostic rules for 23 psy-
chiatric disorders. Using MENTALKG as a
golden-standard logical backbone, we gener-
ate 24,750 synthetic clinical cases that system-
atically vary in information completeness and
diagnostic complexity, enabling low-noise and
interpretable evaluation. Our experiments show
that while state-of-the-art LLMs perform well
on structured queries probing DSM-5 knowl-
edge, they struggle to calibrate confidence in
diagnostic decision-making when distinguish-
ing between clinically overlapping disorders.
These findings reveal evaluation gaps not cap-
tured by existing benchmarks. All resources are
publicly released.1
1
Introduction
The global burden of mental disorders continues to
increase (Organization, 2022), motivating interest
in whether large language models (LLMs) can sup-
port mental health–related analytical tasks (Kim
and Wang, 2025; Tong et al., 2025). Prior work
suggests that LLMs can identify clinically relevant
signals in text and generate plausible diagnostic
hypotheses by leveraging mental health knowledge
acquired during pretraining (Li et al., 2024; Wang
et al., 2024; Omar and Levkovich, 2025). How-
ever, psychiatric diagnosis is a high-stakes, criteria-
driven process, and it remains unclear whether ex-
isting evaluations meaningfully assess how LLMs
apply diagnostic criteria under realistic conditions.
*Equal Contribution
†Corresponding Authors
1https://github.com/HoyunS/MentalBench
A central difficulty in psychiatric diagno-
sis arises from its inherently multi-criteria and
boundary-sensitive decision structure. Diagnostic
judgments are governed by standardized frame-
works such as DSM-5, which require integrating
symptom combinations, duration constraints, func-
tional impairment, exclusion rules, and distinctions
between clinically similar disorders (Clark et al.,
2017). In practice, these judgments are further com-
plicated by incomplete or selectively reported pa-
tient information. As a result, evaluating diagnostic
performance requires benchmarks that go beyond
factual recall of diagnostic criteria and test how
models make decisions when diagnostic bound-
aries are unclear.
Despite this need, existing mental health bench-
marks remain limited. Importantly, this gap reflects
not a lack of interest, but the inherent difficulty
in constructing high-quality psychiatric diagnos-
tic data. Strict privacy regulations, the absence of
objective biomarkers, and the complexity of for-
mal diagnostic logic make large-scale curation of
expert-validated datasets exceptionally challeng-
ing (Ive, 2022; Vedanta and Rao, 2024). Conse-
quently, most benchmarks rely on social media
data and self-reported labels (Yates et al., 2017; Co-
han et al., 2018), which are ill-suited for evaluating
DSM-grounded diagnostic judgments or systematic
differential diagnosis. To date, no benchmark has
been designed to rigorously assess psychiatric diag-
nostic decision-making in controlled yet clinically
grounded settings.
In this work, we introduce MENTALBENCH, a
benchmark designed to address this gap. At its core
is MENTALKG, a psychiatrist-built and validated
knowledge graph that explicitly encodes DSM-5
diagnostic criteria and differential diagnostic rules
for 23 psychiatric disorders. MENTALKG serves
as a golden-standard logical backbone, constructed
with direct expert involvement rather than automat-
ically extracted from text. Leveraging this struc-
1
arXiv:2602.12871v1  [cs.CL]  13 Feb 2026

tured knowledge, we generate diagnostic scenarios
through rule-consistent augmentation and subse-
quently review them with psychiatrists to ensure
clinical plausibility. This design yields synthetic
data with low annotation noise and enables fine-
grained analysis: model errors can be disentangled
into deficiencies in domain knowledge versus fail-
ures in applying diagnostic criteria.
Using MENTALKG as a foundation, MENTAL-
BENCH comprises 24,750 synthetic clinical cases
that systematically vary along two clinically critical
axes: information completeness (from structured
medical–chart–like descriptions to incomplete pa-
tient self-reports) and diagnostic complexity (from
single-disorder cases to challenging differential di-
agnosis scenarios). These controlled variations al-
low us to evaluate not only whether a model can
identify relevant diagnoses, but also whether it can
appropriately determine the number of diagnoses
to commit to in ambiguous settings.
Our experimental results reveal a nuanced limi-
tation of current LLMs. While models demonstrate
strong performance on structured, single-answer
queries that directly probe DSM-5 knowledge, they
struggle when faced with clinically similar dis-
orders where the key challenge lies in deciding
whether to commit to a single diagnosis or retain
multiple plausible alternatives. This difficulty in
calibrating diagnostic commitment, rather than a
lack of factual knowledge, emerges consistently
across model families and remains largely unexam-
ined by existing benchmarks. Our contributions are
threefold:
• We construct MENTALKG, a psychiatrist-built
and validated knowledge graph encoding DSM-
5 diagnostic criteria and differential diagnostic
rules for 23 psychiatric disorders.
• We introduce MENTALBENCH, a clinically
grounded benchmark of 24,750 synthetic diag-
nostic cases generated from expert-curated logic,
enabling low-noise and interpretable evaluation.
• We provide a systematic analysis showing that
current LLMs struggle not with recalling diag-
nostic knowledge, but with calibrating diagnostic
commitment in the presence of clinically over-
lapping conditions.
2
Related Work
2.1
LLMs in Mental Health Diagnosis
Recent studies demonstrate that LLMs can identify
clinically meaningful patterns in text and suggest
potential diagnoses (Yang et al., 2023, 2024; Song
et al., 2025; Ozgun et al., 2025). Despite promising
results, the studies simultaneously revealed limi-
tations in performing diagnostic decision-making.
For instance, Yang et al. (2023) found that LLMs
often fail to identify clinical signals present in text,
leading to inaccurate diagnoses. Similarly, Ozgun
et al. (2025) discovered systematic misclassifica-
tion patterns among clinically similar disorders,
where models frequently confuse adjustment dis-
order with depression and bipolar disorder with
depression. These findings highlight the necessity
of systematically evaluating LLMs’ psychiatric di-
agnostic capabilities before their integration into
real-world clinical practice.
2.2
Benchmarks for Mental Health Diagnosis
Most existing benchmarks for mental health diag-
nosis rely on social media data (Shing et al., 2018;
Ji et al., 2022; Coppersmith et al., 2015b; Pirina and
Çöltekin, 2018), which depend on self-reported la-
bels and lack clinically validated ground truth. This
reliance reflects the inherent difficulty of construct-
ing high-quality psychiatric diagnostic datasets,
given strict privacy regulations, the absence of ob-
jective biomarkers, and the complexity of formal
diagnostic logic. Recent question-answering bench-
marks (Jin et al., 2023; Alhuzali et al., 2024; Racha
et al., 2025) expand beyond social media classifi-
cation, but primarily assess factual knowledge or
cover a limited range of disorders, failing to capture
the decision-making complexity of clinical diag-
nosis. In contrast, MENTALBENCH is built upon
a psychiatrist-validated knowledge graph that ex-
plicitly encodes DSM-5 diagnostic criteria and dif-
ferential diagnostic rules, enabling logic-grounded
evaluation of psychiatric diagnostic capabilities.
2.3
Question Answering Benchmarks in
Medical Domain
In
general
medicine,
benchmarks
such
as
MedQA (Jin et al., 2021), MedMCQA (Pal et al.,
2022), and PubMedQA (Jin et al., 2019) are widely
used to evaluate medical knowledge in LLMs.
However, mental health–related cases form only a
small subset of these datasets and do not reflect the
unique challenges of psychiatric diagnosis, which
often involves ambiguous symptom descriptions
and clinically overlapping conditions. Unlike
general medical QA, psychiatric diagnosis requires
deciding whether to commit to a single diagnosis
or retain multiple plausible alternatives. MEN-

Figure 1: Overview of the knowledge graph schema. The framework models the hierarchical and relational dependencies
between disorders, symptom groups, and symptoms, alongside directional differential diagnoses. The resulting graph comprises
23 Disorder nodes, 23 Symptom Group nodes, 84 Symptom nodes, and 87 Differential Diagnosis nodes. These entities are
interconnected via mandatory edges, included-in (hierarchical) edges, and differential diagnosis edges, forming a dense network
of clinical dependencies.
TALBENCH explicitly models this challenge by
incorporating both informational uncertainty and
diagnostic complexity, which are not addressed by
existing medical benchmarks.
3
MENTALKG
Due to the diagnostic complexity resulting from
overlapping symptoms among psychiatric disor-
ders, generating clinical cases without guiding psy-
chiatric diagnostic criteria can produce clinically
vague cases that lack diagnostic representativeness.
To ensure the clinical reliability of the generated
cases, we construct MENTALKG, a psychiatrist-
validated knowledge graph that structurally for-
malizes DSM-5 (American Psychiatric Association
et al., 2013) diagnostic criteria. Our graph decom-
poses complex clinical diagnostic criteria into four
distinct entity types: Symptom, Symptom Group,
Disorder, and Differential Diagnosis.
3.1
Graph Components
Symptom Nodes.
MENTALKG comprises 84
symptom nodes (S) covering the diagnostic criteria
for 23 mental disorders. Each symptom node con-
tains two attributes: a textual description describing
the clinical meaning of the symptom, and a set of
subtypes representing its specific manifestations.
Symptom Group Nodes.
The DSM-5 often or-
ganizes symptoms into clinically relevant groups,
such as depressive and manic episodes. To rep-
resent this hierarchy, we introduce 23 symptom
group nodes (G), which aggregate related symp-
tom nodes.
Disorder Nodes.
MENTALKG contains 23 dis-
order nodes (D) corresponding to specific mental
disorders in DSM-5, which we select in consulta-
tion with psychiatrists based on two criteria: (1)
high clinical prevalence, (2) need for differential
diagnosis from other disorders. We map DSM-5 di-
agnostic criteria for each disorder in MENTALKG
to a structured graph representation, connecting dis-
order nodes (D) directly to symptom group nodes
(G) to represent the symptoms required for diagno-
sis (details are in Figure 1). For more fine-grained
diagnostic requirements, such as minimum symp-
tom thresholds and duration constraints, we encode
them as internal attributes of the disorder nodes.
Through this process, the natural language descrip-
tions of DSM-5 are effectively transformed into
structurally formalized information in the graph.
Differential Diagnosis Nodes.
In clinical prac-
tice, patients’ self-reports rarely perfectly match
the diagnostic criteria of a single disorder. Chal-
lenges often arise when symptoms overlap, or clin-
ical evidence is inconclusive; for instance, a pa-
tient presenting with depression who also exhibits
manic features requires careful differentiation be-
tween Major Depressive Disorder and Bipolar II
Disorder. To address this, we introduce differential
diagnosis nodes (Dd) connecting a primary sus-
picion (D1) to an alternative (D2) via a directed
edge. This directionality captures scenarios where
a patient resembles D1, but specific confounding
contexts (e.g., ambiguous duration or shared symp-
toms) necessitate the evaluation of D2.
Each node internally encodes the differential
diagnostic criteria using the following three at-
tributes: (1) Triggering Condition, which speci-
fies additional symptoms that prompt the need for
differential diagnosis; (2) Key Difference, which
represents the core points of divergence between
the two disorders; and (3) Discriminating Rules,
which specify conditional decision rules for de-
termining the final diagnosis. For example, when
depressive episodes co-occur with elevated mood,
differential diagnosis between MDD and BD be-
comes necessary. The key difference lies in whether
manic symptoms collectively satisfy the criteria for
a Manic Episode: if so, BD is diagnosed; otherwise,
MDD. Table 4 illustrates this example.

Figure 2: Overview of the clinical case generation framework for constructing MENTALBENCH. Our pipeline consists of three
stages: (1) Symptom Profile Construction, where concrete symptom configurations are sampled from MENTALKG; (2) Patient
Profile Instantiation, which assigns demographic and specific symptom manifestations; and (3) Clinical Case Generation, which
synthesizes clinical cases based on patient profiles. These processes are applied under two clinical scenarios: Single-Disease
Identification and Differential Diagnosis.
3.2
Expert Validation
The entire construction process of MENTALKG
was conducted in collaboration with two experts.
Specifically, the psychiatrist validated the follow-
ing aspects of the graph: (1) the clinical appropriate-
ness of symptom subtypes within symptom nodes,
(2) the alignment of the formalized diagnostic cri-
teria with DSM-5 standards, and (3) the clinical
validity of the differential diagnosis logic. Through
iterative cycles of expert review and refinement, kg
can structurally encode the complex diagnostic cri-
teria and differential diagnostic logic of the DSM-5
rather than simply serving as a simple collection of
disorder–symptom connections. A detailed valida-
tion process is provided in Appendix A.3.
4
MENTALBENCH
Building upon MENTALKG as a structured foun-
dation, we generate MENTALBENCH, a question-
answering benchmark consisting of synthetically
generated clinical cases that describe specific pa-
tients’ psychiatric symptom profiles and their cor-
responding diagnostic options. Following the gen-
eration pipeline illustrated in Figure 2, we generate
four types of clinical cases across two diagnostic
scenarios: (1) Single–Disease Identification (Medi-
cal Chart, Patient Self-Report) and (2) Differential
Diagnosis (Unambiguous, Ambiguous).
4.1
Single–Disease Identification
In this setting, we focus on generating clinical cases
for single-disease identification, where each case
represents a clinically typical presentation for only
a single mental disorder. The following subsections
detail the process of generating clinical cases for
each type.
4.1.1
Symptom Profile Construction
Patients sharing the same psychiatric diagnosis of-
ten exhibit substantial clinical heterogeneity, char-
acterized by diverse symptom combinations and
varying durations. To capture this diversity in the
generated clinical cases, we construct multiple
symptom profiles for each disorder by sampling
symptom configurations from MENTALKG. We
consider two clinical scenarios.
Type 1 – Medical Chart.
This type represents a
clinical scenario in which a psychiatrist has com-
pleted a diagnostic interview with a patient and
documented it in the medical chart. Under the as-
sumption that all information necessary for diag-
nosis has been fully collected, we sample symp-
tom combinations that strictly satisfy all DSM-5
diagnostic requirements, such as meeting the mini-
mum symptom threshold (e.g., at least five required
symptoms for MDD). We generate 5 seed profiles
per disorder for this type.
Type 2 – Patient Self-Report.
This type reflects
a scenario in which patients directly describe their
subjective distress to clinicians in their own words.
Motivated by the clinical reality that patients tend
to focus on chief complaints while omitting sec-
ondary symptoms (Feng et al., 2021; McBride et al.,
2018), we sample incomplete symptom profiles
from MENTALKG that include core symptoms of
the target disorder but fall below the DSM-5 di-
agnostic threshold (e.g., only three symptoms for
MDD). In this type, we generate ten seed profiles
per disorder.

the primate enclosure to the big cats, barely speaking. I find myself just bursting
into tears for no reason, sometimes right there in front of the capybaras. Then the
guilt cycles start – replaying every single mistake I’ve ever made, every animal I
could’ve fed better. .... No plan, just this sudden, horrific impulse. It’s draining,
utterly draining. Sometimes, maybe for a day or two, I’ll feel a burst of energy,
almost too much, and I’ll get a bunch of projects done around the house really
fast, but it never lasts. Then it’s back to this.
Lately, it feels like I'm moving through mud. Getting out of bed is a
monumental effort, and I drag myself around the enclosures, feeling
sluggish and heavy. Everything seems to take an eternity. I’ve been crying
a lot too, often for no reason at all, just sudden bursts of tears I can’t stop ....
It's been like this for about five months now, making it almost impossible
to focus on my duties. Sometimes I get brief bursts of energy, feeling pretty
good for an hour or so, a slight lift in my mood, but it never lasts, and I've
assured my doctor I've never experienced such an episode before.

discriminating rules to yield a definitive diagnosis.
Option Choices.
For each sampled symptom pro-
file, we assign four diagnostic options. To evaluate
whether models can discriminate between clinically
similar disorders with a precise understanding of
diagnostic criteria, distractors are selected from
MENTALKG as disorders that share overlapping
symptoms with the target disorder.
4.1.2
Patient Profile Instantiation
We convert symptom profiles into concrete patient
profiles by assigning demographic attributes and
specific symptom manifestations. Demographic in-
formation is sampled from pre-generated combina-
tions produced using Gemini-2.5-Pro, and one pre-
defined subtype is selected for each symptom node.
This process yields five distinct patient profiles per
symptom profile, capturing variability in clinical
presentation. Further details on the demographic
sampling process are provided in Appendix B.1.
4.1.3
Clinical Case Generation
The initialized patient profiles are converted into
natural language using two styles aligned with the
scenario types in Section 4.1.1. Profiles in the Med-
ical Chart use a third-person perspective and clin-
ical terminology to simulate psychiatrists’ notes,
whereas profiles in the Patient Self-Report use a
first-person perspective and colloquial language to
reflect patients’ subjective reports. All scenarios
are constrained to 150–200 words and instructed
to avoid mentioning diagnostic labels. For each pa-
tient profile, we generate three scenarios per type
using three LLMs—GPT-4.1, Gemini 2.5 Pro, and
Qwen3-235B—to mitigate model-specific stylistic
bias.
4.2
Differential Diagnosis
We next construct differential diagnosis cases to
evaluate models’ ability to distinguish among clini-
cally similar disorders with overlapping symptom
profiles. We generate two types of cases: Ambigu-
ous, which maintain clinical plausibility for multi-
ple disorders by leveraging shared symptoms, and
Unambiguous cases, which incorporate explicit dis-
criminative cues that resolve the case to a single
diagnosis.
4.2.1
Symptom Profile Construction
We construct symptom profiles by injecting differ-
ential diagnosis logic defined in MENTALKG into
the predefined symptom profiles from Section 4.1.1.
This design choice is motivated by the fact that
symptom profiles fully satisfying diagnostic crite-
ria for a specific disorder typically do not require
differential diagnosis, whereas partially satisfied
profiles leave room for multiple potential diagnoses
that can be shifted by subtle clinical nuances. We
define two differential diagnosis scenarios:
Type 3 – Ambiguous.
These cases represent diag-
nostically ambiguous situations in which more than
one disorder remains clinically plausible. We con-
struct these cases by injecting the Triggering Con-
dition from the target differential diagnosis node,
which introduces additional symptoms that allow
multiple candidate diagnoses to remain plausible.
Type 4 – Unambiguous.
These cases represent
diagnostic scenarios in which multiple disorders
are initially plausible, but explicit discriminative
cues enable the case to be resolved to a single diag-
nosis. We construct them by augmenting ambigu-
ous symptom profiles with Key Differences and
Discriminating Rules defined in the corresponding
differential diagnosis nodes, yielding two variants
per profile that resolve to either the original target
diagnosis or the differential diagnosis.
Option Choices.
We include the target and dif-
ferential diagnoses as the primary options, with
two additional distractors selected from less related

4.2.2
Clinical Case Generation
Differential diagnosis symptom profiles are instan-
tiated into patient profiles using the same procedure
as described in Section 4.1.2. For each profile, five
patient variants are generated. All differential diag-
nosis cases are generated in the Patient Self-Report
style using the pipeline described in Section 4.1.3.
Representative examples of these generated cases
are illustrated in Figure 3.
4.3
Data Statistics
We generate 24,750 clinical cases in total, com-
prising 1,725 for Medical Chart, 3,450 for Patient
Self-Report, 6,525 for Ambiguous, and 13,050 for
Unambiguous cases. Detailed statistics for each
generation stage are summarized in Table 7.
4.4
Expert Validation
All constructed seed profiles are reviewed by two
psychiatrists to ensure the clinical reliability of the
generated clinical cases. Profiles that insufficiently
represented the target disorder or exhibited clini-
cally ambiguous profiles are revised based on the
feedback. To further assess the quality of the gen-
erated cases, two experts evaluate 220 randomly
sampled scenarios across all scenario types using
a 5-point Likert scale. The evaluation considers
three dimensions: Linguistic Naturalness, Diagnos-
tic Validity, and Clinical Realism. With high inter-
annotator agreement, the mean scores are 4.95,
4.44, and 4.89, respectively, indicating consistently
high ratings across all evaluation dimensions. We
report detailed results of expert validation in Ap-
pendix B.2.
5
Experiments and Analysis
We conduct a comprehensive evaluation of diverse
LLMs on MENTALBENCH to assess their psychi-
atric diagnostic capabilities in clinical settings.
5.1
Experimental Setup
We employ closed-source models from the GPT,
Gemini, and Claude families, as well as open-
source models including Qwen 2.5, Qwen 3,
Gemma 3, Llama-3.1, and MentaLLaMA. Notably,
MentaLLaMA (Yang et al., 2024) is a special-
ized model fine-tuned from Llama-2 for the men-
tal health domain. For Types 1 and 2, models are
instructed to select a single answer, whereas for
Types 3 and 4, they are directed to choose one
or more answers. Details of the model versions,
prompts, and settings are in Appendix D. We mea-
sure accuracy using an exact match metric, recog-
nizing a prediction as correct only if it identifies
the complete set of ground-truth answers.
5.2
Diagnostic Capability Assessment
Performance Trends by Scale and Architecture.
The evaluation results for diverse model families
on MENTALBENCH are shown in Table 1. Eval-
uation results show a clear hierarchy: proprietary
models generally outperform open-source models,
and performance generally improves with model
scale, confirming that the benchmark effectively
measures fundamental diagnostic capacity. Notably,
MentaLLaMA significantly underperforms despite
domain specialization, suggesting that its reliance
on the older Llama-2 architecture and social me-
dia training data does not generalize to rigorous
clinical diagnosis.
Information Incompleteness and Diagnostic
Trade-offs.
Scenario analysis highlights critical
reasoning gaps. A universal performance drop from
Type 1 to Type 2 exposes the challenge of informa-
tion incompleteness, as models struggle to map

5.3
Disease-level Analysis
LLMs Struggle with Underrepresented Disor-
ders.
We further investigate the disease-specific
performance of LLMs to better understand diag-
nostic accuracy at the level of individual disorders.
Figure 4 presents the accuracy heatmaps for each
of the 23 mental disorders under the Type 2 set-
ting. The results show marked limitations within
the D003–D007 cluster (spanning ADHD and the
Schizophrenia spectrum), where accuracy drops
significantly across most models. Crucially, this
performance degradation aligns with the coverage
analysis in Appendix A.1, which identifies that
disorders in this cluster—particularly Schizoaffec-
tive Disorder (D006, D007)—have been largely
excluded from prior research. This correlation sug-
gests that the historical lack of comprehensive
benchmarks has induced a blind spot in current
LLMs, making them unreliable for conditions over-
looked in existing datasets.
Symptomatic Overlap Drives Diagnostic Com-
plexity.
To investigate the impact of symptomatic
overlap on model decision-making, we analyze re-
sults in the unambiguous scenarios (Type 4) by
disease category. We focus on disorder groups that
share overlapping dominant symptoms: depressive
episodes and psychotic features. Figure 5 visualizes
the mapping between the ground-truth diagnoses
(left) and model predictions (right), demonstrating
significant entanglement within these symptomati-
cally similar clusters.

confusion observed here suggests that current mod-
els lack the ability to differentiate these conditions
based on fine-grained differential criteria (e.g., the
concurrence of mood episodes with psychosis), un-
derscoring an urgent need for future work to ad-
dress these complex diagnoses.
5.4
Error Patterns Analysis
Models Struggle to Calibrate Diagnostic Com-
mitment.
To investigate the reasoning failures
driving the performance divergence observed in
Table 1, we conduct a fine-grained error analysis
on Type 3 (Ambiguous) and Type 4 (Unambiguous)
scenarios. We categorize errors into three distinct
types: (1) Over-diagnosis, where the model pre-
dicts supersets of the ground truth (i.e., failing to
rule out distractors); (2) Under-diagnosis, where

Figure 6 illustrates the distribution of these er-
ror types, showing a fundamental failure to cali-
brate diagnostic commitment. Open-source mod-
els exhibit excessive commitment in Type 4, lead-
ing to widespread Over-diagnosis because they
fail to apply exclusionary rules. Conversely, pro-
prietary models appear rigidly calibrated toward
decisiveness in Type 3, resulting in frequent Under-
diagnosis (insufficient commitment) by forcing
single-label predictions even when clinical evi-
dence supports multiple conditions. This diver-
gence highlights that current models lack the adap-
tive reasoning required to achieve this calibration,
resulting in oscillation between excessive inclusiv-
ity and rigid strictness depending on the model
architecture. Analysis using other metrics is also
presented in Appendix C.1.
Models Lack Intrinsic Constraint Awareness.
Motivated by these calibration failures, we investi-
gate the impact of prompt constraints to determine
whether the performance gap stems from a lack of
clinical knowledge or an inability to infer decision
boundaries. Specifically, we compare performance
in the Type 4 setting across three instruction lev-
els, where the prompt explicitly directs the model
to ‘choose all applicable diagnoses’ (Multiple),
‘choose one or more answers’ (Hybrid), or ‘choose
only one answer’ (Single)2.
Figure 7 presents the performance results for
each prompting strategy. All models perform ro-
bustly under the Single-answer constraint but strug-
gle significantly in the Multiple- and Hybrid-
answer settings. These results indicate that while
models possess the correct latent clinical knowl-
2The prompts are listed in Appendix D.3.
edge (evidenced by high accuracy when the search
space is restricted), they lack the intrinsic aware-
ness to infer diagnostic cardinality from clinical
evidence alone. Without an explicit external con-
straint, models fail to self-regulate, struggling to
distinguish between a primary diagnosis and po-
tential distractors. Notably, although the specific
failure patterns in the Hybrid setting vary by model
(tending toward either over- or under-diagnosis), a
consistent trend emerges: performance improves
significantly across models when they are explicitly
informed that there is only one correct answer. This
reliance on explicit instructions exposes a critical
limitation: current models cannot autonomously
calibrate their prediction cardinality, a fundamen-
tal requirement for real-world diagnosis where the
number of conditions is never pre-defined.
6
Conclusion
We introduce MENTALBENCH, a benchmark
grounded in MENTALKG for rigorously evaluating
psychiatric diagnostic reasoning. While our exper-
iments confirm that LLMs possess robust latent
knowledge of DSM-5 criteria, they exhibit critical
diagnostic failures when applied to clinical scenar-
ios. We find that models struggle to handle informa-
tion incompleteness, with performance collapsing
when shifting from structured charts to subjective
patient narratives. Furthermore, models fail to cali-
brate diagnostic commitment, oscillating between
excessive inclusivity and rigid strictness, and lack
the intrinsic constraint awareness to define deci-
sion boundaries without explicit prompting. These
findings confirm that MENTALBENCH poses a sub-
stantial diagnostic challenge to current state-of-the-
art models. By establishing a rigorous evaluation
framework, MENTALBENCH advocates for future
research to prioritize the adaptive, robust decision-
making essential for real-world psychiatry.
8

Limitations
Despite its contributions, this study has several
limitations. First, the clinical cases in MENTAL-
BENCH are constructed as descriptive narratives
rather than interactive dialogues. While real psychi-
atric diagnosis involves iterative clinician–patient
conversations, our benchmark is intentionally de-
signed to evaluate models’ ability to apply clini-
cally grounded diagnostic criteria under controlled
and interpretable scenarios. Future work will lever-
age the constructed knowledge graph to simulate
doctor–patient interactions and assess additional
diagnostic capabilities such as follow-up question
selection.
Second, all clinical cases are generated exclu-
sively in English, limiting generalizability across
languages and cultural contexts where psychiatric
symptoms may be expressed differently. However,
the knowledge graph encodes DSM-5–based di-
agnostic logic in a language-independent manner,
making its structure applicable across diverse lin-
guistic and cultural settings. This allows future
extensions to multilingual and culturally diverse
benchmarks through prompt-level control.
Finally, our evaluation focuses on models’ fi-
nal diagnostic outputs and observable error pat-
terns, without directly examining whether their
internal reasoning aligns with DSM-5 diagnostic
criteria. While this design enables systematic anal-
ysis of how models apply diagnostic knowledge
at the output level, it does not capture whether
their intermediate reasoning processes follow clin-
ically grounded diagnostic logic. In future work,
we plan to augment MENTALBENCH with explicit,
criterion-level diagnostic reasoning, allowing the
benchmark to more directly assess models’ diag-
nostic reasoning behaviors.
Ethical Considerations
MENTALBENCH includes only clinically grounded
synthesized clinical cases and does not contain any
real patient data, medical records, or personally
identifiable information. While some synthesized
cases may describe severe psychiatric symptoms,
including suicidal ideation or self-harm, such con-
tent is presented as clinically descriptive accounts
of symptoms that focus on patients’ reported ex-
periences, without including explicit descriptions
of suicidal methods or self-harm behaviors. Ad-
ditionally, although MENTALBENCH is designed
to reflect a wide range of clinically realistic diag-
nostic scenarios, the benchmark does not capture
the full complexity of real-world clinical practice,
as discussed in the limitations. Consequently, the
evaluation results do not guarantee real-world clin-
ical performance and must be utilized under expert
guidance.

A
Details of Knowledge Graph
A.1
Scope of Disorders
In this section, we provide a comprehensive de-
scription of the constructed MENTALKG and its
constituent elements, with a particular focus on the
scope of mental health conditions covered.
Limited Scope of Prior Benchmarks
Table 3
presents a comparative analysis of disorder cover-
age across prominent mental health datasets and
benchmarks established in recent years. As illus-
trated, prior research has predominantly concen-
trated on high-prevalence conditions, specifically
Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), Generalized
Anxiety Disorder (GAD), and PTSD. While these
conditions are critical, this narrow focus leaves a
significant portion of the DSM-5 diagnostic spec-
trum unexplored in the context of LLM evaluation.
Notably, complex psychopathological profiles
and distinct subtypes remain largely underrepre-
sented. For instance, distinctions within Schizoaf-
fective Disorders (Bipolar vs. Depressive types)
and specific subtypes of Bipolar Disorder (I vs. II
vs. with Psychotic features) are rarely explicitly
modeled in existing datasets. Furthermore, condi-
tions such as Delusional Disorder, Specific Pho-
bias, and various Feeding and Eating Disorders
(e.g., Binge-Eating Disorder) often lack dedicated
evaluation benchmarks.
Scope of MENTALBENCH
Table 2 presents the
complete list of 23 disorders included in our work.
To ensure a holistic evaluation of psychopatholog-
ical reasoning, we selected representative disor-
ders across a wide spectrum of diagnostic cate-
gories defined in the DSM-5. Our coverage en-
compasses Anxiety Disorders (e.g., GAD, Spe-
cific Phobia), Obsessive-Compulsive and Related
Disorders (e.g., OCD, Body Dysmorphic Dis-
order), Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorders
(e.g., PTSD, Adjustment Disorder), Mood Disor-
ders (e.g., MDD, BD I and II), the Schizophrenia
Spectrum (e.g., Delusional Disorder, Schizophre-
nia), Feeding and Eating Disorders (e.g., Anorexia
Nervosa, Binge-Eating Disorder), and Attention-
Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD).
Crucially, our selection criteria prioritize the
replication of authentic challenges encountered in
real-world clinical settings, specifically address-
ing the diagnostic ambiguities posed by symptom
overlap and subtle phenomenological distinctions.
Since precise differentiation among these condi-
tions is a prerequisite for identifying the primary

interventions, we deliberately included disorders
where accurate diagnosis hinges on fine-grained
clinical details.
For instance, we explicitly distinguish between
the three presentations of ADHD—Combined, Inat-
tentive, and Hyperactive—to test the model’s abil-
ity to identify specific behavioral nuances. Further-
more, we address the complex comorbidities found
at the intersection of mood and psychotic symp-
toms, which represent a significant diagnostic hur-
dle. To capture this, we include Schizoaffective Dis-
order (both Bipolar and Depressive types) along-
side Mood Disorders with Psychotic Features (BD
I with psychotic features and MDD with psychotic
features). While these conditions often present with
identical symptoms, accurate diagnosis relies on an-
alyzing duration, symptom concurrence, and sever-
ity. By including these confounding cases, we rig-
orously test the LLM’s depth of expert-level psy-
chiatric knowledge.
Regarding the target demographic, our bench-
mark focuses on adult clinical narratives. Conse-
quently, we generally exclude neurocognitive and
neurodevelopmental disorders (e.g., Alzheimer’s
Disease) and conditions primarily diagnosed in
early childhood (e.g., Conduct Disorder). How-

Although classified as a neurodevelopmental disor-

Disorder
Each disorder node encapsulates the
core diagnostic prerequisites and exclusion criteria

• Name: The standardized clinical designation of the con-
dition
– Major Depressive Disorder

condition’s validity

• Traumatic Stressor: Specifies if exposure to a trau-
matic event is a prerequisite
– False
• Psychosocial Stressor: Specifies if a specific psychoso-
cial stressor is a prerequisite
– False
• Additional Requirements: Supplementary exclusion
criteria or specific conditions necessary for a valid diag-
nosis
– None
Symptom Group
These nodes represent logical

cluster

A.3
Details of Expert Validation
To ensure the clinical reliability of the constructed
MENTALKG, the entire development process is
conducted in collaboration with mental health ex-
perts. Specifically, the experts perform a rigorous
validation focusing on three key aspects:
1) Clinical Appropriateness of Subtypes within
Symptom Nodes
Experts verify whether the phe-
notypic manifestations (Subtypes) listed under
each symptom node accurately represented the core
clinical concept of that node. During this process,
subtypes that are semantically ambiguous or ex-
hibited significant overlap with other nodes are
removed or reassigned. For instance, Hopelessness
(S083), initially categorized as a subtype of the
Depressed Mood (S024) node, is separated into a
distinct symptom node to accurately implement the
specific diagnostic criteria for Persistent Depres-
sive Disorder.
2) Alignment with DSM-5 Standards
Experts
review the structural connections between Symp-
tom and Symptom Group nodes, as well as the
logic encoded in node attributes, to ensure they
faithfully reflect the formal diagnostic criteria of
the DSM-5. During this review, experts manually
encoded Additional Requirements (e.g., exclusion
criteria) into disorder nodes to sharpen the decision
boundaries between clinically similar conditions if
needed.
3) Clinical Validity of Differential Diagnosis
Logic
Since DSM-5 differential diagnosis guide-
lines are originally presented as unstructured text,
we converted them into structured logical rules.
Experts evaluate the discriminating rules within
differential diagnosis nodes to ensure they appro-
priately capture real-world patterns of diagnostic
confusion and the discrimination logic between
paired disorders. Through this iterative review, am-
biguous rules are refined or discarded, and specific
conditional contexts are added to establish clearer
discrimination criteria.
This rigorous validation process ensures that
MENTALKG successfully transforms the complex
diagnostic systems and differential diagnoses of
the DSM-5 across 23 disorders into a structured
format with a high level of clinical fidelity.

Result
To ensure the clinical reliability and qual-
ity of the generated scenarios, we conduct a rig-
orous human evaluation involving domain experts.
One psychiatrist and one clinical psychologist inde-
pendently review a random sample of 220 scenar-
ios generated by our framework. The evaluation is
conduct using a 5-point Likert scale (1=Very Poor
to 5=Excellent) across three key dimensions: (1)
Linguistic Naturalness, assessing whether the text
flows naturally like a human patient; (2) Diagnostic
Validity, verifying if the clinical logic and symp-
tom presentation align with DSM-5 criteria; and (3)
Clinical Realism, evaluating whether the scenario
reflects the complexity and nuance of real-world
clinical encounters.

Table 6 summarizes the results. The generated
scenarios receive consistently high ratings from
both experts, with mean scores exceeding 4.3
across all dimensions. Notably, Linguistic Natural-
ness achieves near-perfect scores (4.94 and 4.97),
and Clinical Realism is rated highly (4.84 and
4.94), demonstrating that our LLM-based gener-
ation pipeline successfully captures the subtleties
of patient narratives.
Inter-Annotator Agreement Analysis
To assess
the reliability of the expert ratings, we report Per-
cent Agreement, Cohen’s κw (quadratic weighted;
Cohen (1968)), and Gwet’s AC2 (Gwet, 2008). As
shown in the table, we observe a discrepancy where
high Percent Agreement (e.g., 93.2% for Linguis-
tic Naturalness) is accompanied by low κw values
(e.g., 0.041). This is well known as the prevalence
paradox or kappa paradox (Feinstein and Cicchetti,
1990), where chance-corrected agreement is arti-
ficially underestimated when rating distributions
are highly skewed. Cohen’s κ penalizes agreement
when the marginal distribution of ratings is highly
skewed. However, in our case, the overwhelming
prevalence of high scores (4s and 5s) inflates the
probability of chance agreement (Pe), mathemati-
cally suppressing the κ value despite strong actual
consensus between annotators.
To address this limitation, we adopt Gwet’s AC2
as our primary reliability metric, as it is robust to
prevalence effects while maintaining chance cor-
rection (Gwet, 2008). The AC2 scores indicate sub-
stantial reliability (ranging from 0.499 to 0.691),
supporting the conclusion that the high ratings re-
flect genuine consensus on the dataset’s high qual-
ity rather than random chance.

Type 4 (Unambiguous)
In the Type 4 setting,
where exactly one diagnosis is correct, both open
and closed models maintain consistently high re-
call (≈0.93–0.96), suggesting that the correct di-
agnosis is almost always included in the response.
However, precision diverges sharply: open models
show low precision (≈0.50–0.57), while closed
models achieve higher but still imperfect precision
(≈0.71–0.82). Given the uniformly high recall, this
precision gap implies that models frequently select
additional, unnecessary diagnoses even when the
task is unambiguous, resulting in systematic over-
diagnosis. This pattern aligns with Figure 6, where
overdiagnosis errors dominate the error distribution
in Type 4 tasks, confirming that the primary failure
lies in regulating prediction cardinality rather than
identifying the correct diagnosis.
Overall, these findings reveal a calibration fail-
ure in diagnostic strictness. The persistent pattern
of high recall but low precision shows that mod-
els favor inclusive prediction strategies that ensure
the correct diagnosis is selected, yet fail to reliably
exclude clinically similar distractors. This imbal-
ance reflects an inability to internally regulate the
trade-off between inclusivity and exclusion, lead-
ing to systematic over-diagnosis in unambiguous
cases and under-diagnosis in ambiguous ones. As
a result, current LLMs struggle to infer appropriate
diagnostic cardinality from evidence alone, limit-
ing their reliability in real-world clinical settings.
C.2
LLM Data Generation Bias Analysis
(Analysis of Self-Recognition Bias)
The dataset constructed in this study consists of
augmented data generated partitions using the GPT,
Gemini, and Qwen model families. Such a gener-
ation method may raise concerns regarding “self-
bias,” where a specific model might recognize its
own generated problems more effectively or ex-
hibit relatively higher performance compared to
18

problems generated by other models.
To investigate this possibility, we compare the ac-
curacy rates across different combinations of data
generation models and evaluation models. Table
9 presents the evaluation results of three models
(GPT-5.1, Gemini-2.5-Pro, and Qwen3-235) serv-
ing as evaluators for the datasets generated by each
respective model. The experimental results indi-
cate that all evaluation models recorded consistent
performance metrics regardless of the data source.
Specifically, GPT-5.1 shows no significant per-
formance discrepancy between its self-generated
data (0.3549) and data generated by other mod-
els (0.3670, 0.3601). This trend is consistently ob-
served for Gemini-2.5-Pro and Qwen3-235 as well.
This implies that the models do not identify the
source of the data to produce biased evaluations.
Furthermore, it substantiates that the multi-model-
based data augmentation technique employed in
this study has secured objective data quality that is
not dependent on a specific model.

D.2
Experimental Settings
The inference environments were configured based
on the model access methods. The GPT series
were accessed via the OpenAI Platform, while the
Gemini and Claude series were utilized through
the OpenRouter Platform. In contrast, all open-
weights models, including Qwen3-235B-A22B,
were hosted in a self-managed environment. We
performed inference using the vLLM library on
an AWS p5en.48xlarge instance equipped with 8
NVIDIA H200 GPUs.

System Prompt for Type 1 Generation
SYSTEM:
You are a psychiatrist.
After interviewing a patient , document the case presentation in medical chart format.
# Goal
Create a professional ** Clinical Case Summary ** (Third -person perspective) based on
the target symptoms and demographics.
# Guidelines
** Perspective :**
- Write in third -person
- Refer to the patient as "The patient" or "A [Age]-year -old [Gender ]"
** Patient Demographics :**
- Include age , gender , marital status , occupation in the opening
- Avoid temporal modifiers (e.g., "recently retired", "newly divorced ")
- IMPORTANT: Provided demographics are NOT stressors or causes of symptoms
- For potentially stressor -like demographics (e.g., retirement , divorce , bereavement):
a. Add a statement showing clear temporal separation between the demographic event
and symptom onset
b. The demographic event should have occurred significantly earlier than symptom
onset
** Terminology & Tone :**
- Use standard medical terminology (avoid patient slang)
- Maintain an objective , clinical tone
** Constraints :**
- Do not reveal the diagnosis name
- Do not directly quote or copy the provided symptom descriptions
** Requirements :**
- Include the duration in clinical format
- Incorporate all provided symptom categories as clinical observations
- Keep the summary concise (approximately 150 -200 words)
